title: What happens if you guess? - Leigh Nataro

multiple-choice.question: What is probability used for in weather forecasts?

options.label: A
options.text: To determine the time of sunrise.

options.label: B
options.text: To determine the temperature of the day.

options.label: C
options.text: To determine the chance of precipitation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of getting a perfect score by guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
What is the average score you would get by randomly guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
What is the probability of getting all 20 questions correct by randomly guessing on a 20-question multiple-choice test with 5 possible answers for each question?
What should you expect your score to be if you randomly guess on a 20-question multiple-choice test with 5 possible answers for each question?
What is the glue that connects people in journalism.
What is the trifecta of sourcing in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources, overview sources, and unofficial sources

options.label: B
options.text: Official sources, unofficial sources, and consultants

options.label: C
options.text: Overview sources, unofficial sources, and authors

multiple-choice.question: What type of sources provide the "why" behind a story?
What is the purpose of asking surprising questions in journalism?

options.label: C
options.text: To achieve a complicated, fragile human connection

options.label: D
options.text: To present bulleted facts and updates

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of anecdote in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To present bulleted facts and updates

options.label: C
options.text: To breathe life into a grey story of exposition, facts, and data

multiple-choice.question: When is it important to convey information quickly in journalism?

options.label: B
options.text: When a story has the luxury of a slow dance of information

options.label: D
options.text: When a situation is not urgent

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of narrative personal stories in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To present bulleted facts and updates

options.label: C
options.text: To deliver the narrative bond that will connect us to each other

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of unofficial sources in the trifecta of sourcing?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide the numbers and answers to how much, how many, where, when, and who

options.label: C
options.text: To provide the why and give consequence on the event, trend, phase, or idea

options.label: D
options.text: To provide the facts and data

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of regarding the stories of every subject as sacred in journalism?

options.label: C
options.text: To achieve a complicated, fragile human connection

options.label: D
options.text: To deliver the narrative bond that will connect us to each other

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of academics, consultants, and authors in the trifecta of sourcing?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide the numbers and answers to how much, how many, where, when, and who

options.label: C
options.text: To provide the why and give consequence on the event, trend, phase, or idea

options.label: D
options.text: To provide the facts and data

title: How fiction can change reality - Jessica Wise

multiple-choice.question: What does the author mean by saying "There is no frigate like a book to take us lands away..."?

options.label: A
options.text: That books are a great way to escape reality.

options.label: B
options.text: That books are a great way to learn new things.

options.label: C
options.text: That books are a great way to make new friends.

options.label: D
options.text: That books are a great way to make money.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the ways that stories can change a person's point of view?

options.label: A
options.text: By showing them new places and cultures.

options.label: B
options.text: By teaching them new skills and facts.

options.label: C
options.text: By helping them understand different perspectives and ideas.

options.label: D
options.text: By giving them new opinions and biases.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a novel that challenged traditional ideas about class and marriage?
What is one of the ways that novels have helped shape the minds of thought leaders across history?

options.label: A
options.text: By providing them with new ideas and perspectives.

options.label: B
options.text: By giving them new skills and knowledge.

options.label: C
options.text: By inspiring them to create new works of art.

options.label: D
options.text: By helping them understand different cultures and societies.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a story that might lead us to think about capitalism in a new way?
What is an example of a story that might reflect the dangers of pursuing a perfect body and letting the media define what is beautiful?
What is an example of a story that might chart a course for understanding animals and our place in their world?
What is the main idea of the author's final question?

options.label: A
options.text: What is the best book to read next?

options.label: B
options.text: What is the most important thing to learn from stories?

options.label: C
options.text: What story will you try on next?

options.label: D
options.text: What is the most popular book of all time?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main concept that logarithms deal with?

options.label: C
options.text: Both extremely small and large numbers.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither extremely small nor large numbers.

multiple-choice.question: What is the value of log base 10 of 10,000?
What is the base of the logarithm that most calculators have a button for?
What is the pH formula that uses logarithms?

options.label: A
options.text: pH equals log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: B
options.text: pH equals negative log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: C
options.text: pH equals log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration squared

options.label: D
options.text: pH equals negative log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration squared

multiple-choice.question: What is the pH of water samples with hydrogen ion concentrations of point 0000000398 and point 00000000398?
What happens to your eyes when they are exposed to a pH of 8.4?
What is the base that is used in the example of log base 2 of 64?
What is the value of log base 2 of 64?
What is the main use of logarithms in chemistry?

options.label: A
options.text: Finding the pH of water samples.

options.label: B
options.text: Finding the concentration of hydrogen ions.

options.label: C
options.text: Finding the concentration of oxygen molecules.

options.label: D
options.text: Finding the concentration of carbon dioxide.

multiple-choice.question: What is the formula for finding the pH of water samples?

options.label: A
options.text: pH equals log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: B
options.text: pH equals negative log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: C
options.text: pH equals log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration squared

options.label: D
options.text: pH equals negative log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration squared

title: The history of keeping time - Karen Mensing

multiple-choice.question: What was the first form of telling time?
What object casts the shadow on a sundial?

options.label: A
options.text: A stick in the center known as a gnomon

options.label: B
options.text: A stick in the center known as a pendulum

options.label: C
options.text: A stick in the center known as a quartz crystal

options.label: D
options.text: A stick in the center known as a candle

multiple-choice.question: What is a device in which fine sand pours through a tiny hole at a constant rate to indicate a predetermined passage of time?
What sparked a big change in traditional timekeeping methods in the 13th century?

options.label: A
options.text: The invention of the atomic clock

options.label: B
options.text: The invention of the mechanical clock

multiple-choice.question: What is the basis for scientific time today?

options.label: A
options.text: A continuous count of seconds based on atomic clocks all around the world

options.label: B
options.text: A continuous count of minutes based on mechanical clocks all around the world

options.label: C
options.text: A continuous count of hours based on sundials all around the world

options.label: D
options.text: A continuous count of days based on hourglasses all around the world

multiple-choice.question: Why does it matter that we keep track of time?

options.label: A
options.text: So we can accurately communicate with people all over the world

options.label: B
options.text: So we can accurately communicate with people in the same city

options.label: C
options.text: So we can accurately communicate with people in the same country

options.label: D
options.text: So we can accurately communicate with people in the same neighborhood

multiple-choice.question: What is a time zone?

options.label: A
options.text: A region on earth that has a uniform standard time

options.label: B
options.text: A region on earth that has a uniform standard temperature

options.label: C
options.text: A region on earth that has a uniform standard humidity

options.label: D
options.text: A region on earth that has a uniform standard wind speed

multiple-choice.question: How many time zones are there on land?
